Practicals

  • Practical Three

On this page

  • 1. Display the flights dataset in an alternative format to simply printing it
  • 2. Rewrite the following code using dplyr and the pipe.
  • 3. Explain why the standard deviation in NA for one carrier and why it is 0 for others?
  • 4. Using tidyr and dplyr where appropriate, construct a dataframe where carriers are along the columns and the rows are the avg dep_delays flown by each character in a month
  • 5. Calculate the proportion of flights that were delayed but arrived on or before time.
  • 6. Using the airlines and the flights data set, do the following and show the output:
    • 6.1 Identify routes that more than 1 airline flies
    • 6.2 For each of those routes, calculate the avg arrival delay for each airline
    • 6.3 For each of those routes, identify the airline with the worst and best average arrival delay
    • 6.4 Identify the route with the biggest difference between the best and worst performing airlines
    • 6.5 Determine the reason for the difference
  • 7. Identify all columns with missing entries, typos and other inconsistencies in the dataset

Practical Three

2. Rewrite the following code using dplyr and the pipe.

The code that needs to be re-written:

flight1 <- flights[flights$month == 1, ]
carrier_vec <- unique(flight1$carrier)
carrier_dist_vec_mean <- numeric(length(carrier_vec))
carrier_dist_vec_sd <- numeric(length(carrier_vec))
for (i in seq_along(carrier_vec)) {
  carrier_dist_vec_mean[i] <- mean(
    flight1$distance[flight1$carrier == carrier_vec[i]]
   )
  carrier_dist_vec_sd[i] <- sd(
    flight1$distance[flight1$carrier == carrier_vec[i]]
  )
}
dist_tbl <- tibble(
  carrier = carrier_vec,
  mean_distance = carrier_dist_vec_mean,
  sd_distance = carrier_dist_vec_sd
)
dist_tbl[order(dist_tbl$mean_distance), ]
# A tibble: 16 × 3
   carrier mean_distance sd_distance
   <chr>           <dbl>       <dbl>
 1 YV               229          0  
 2 9E               476.       334. 
 3 EV               522.       294. 
 4 US               536.       553. 
 5 MQ               566.       223. 
 6 FL               691.       142. 
 7 OO               733         NA  
 8 WN               942.       496. 
 9 B6              1062.       681. 
10 DL              1220.       644. 
11 AA              1350.       626. 
12 UA              1462.       778. 
13 F9              1620          0  
14 AS              2402          0  
15 VX              2495.        98.2
16 HA              4983          0

The re-written code:

dist_tbl <- flights |>
  filter(month == 1) |>
  group_by(carrier) |>
  summarise(mean_distance = mean(distance), sd_distance = sd(distance)) |>
  arrange(mean_distance)
dist_tbl
# A tibble: 16 × 3
   carrier mean_distance sd_distance
   <chr>           <dbl>       <dbl>
 1 YV               229          0  
 2 9E               476.       334. 
 3 EV               522.       294. 
 4 US               536.       553.

12 UA              1462.       778.

14 AS              2402          0

16 HA              4983          0

3. Explain why the standard deviation in NA for one carrier and why it is 0 for others?

The standard deviation is NA becasue there is only 1 record where Carrier OO has month = 1.

flights |>
  filter(carrier == "OO" & month == 1) |>
  select(carrier, distance)
# A tibble: 1 × 2
  carrier distance
  <chr>      <dbl>
1 OO           733

This means that when the standard deviation is calulated from the sample, the sum of squares of the distance is divided by n-1, however since n=1, the denominator becomes 0 and therefore the standard deviation result is NA.

The standard deviation is 0 for others because the the values are the same as the mean in the dataset. Below is an example of one of the rows that have a standard deviation of 0, looked at in more depth.

flights |>
  filter(carrier == "YV" & month == 1) |>
  select(carrier, distance)
# A tibble: 46 × 2
   carrier distance
   <chr>      <dbl>
 1 YV           229
 2 YV           229
 3 YV           229
 4 YV           229
 5 YV           229
 6 YV           229
 7 YV           229
 8 YV           229
 9 YV           229
10 YV           229
# ℹ 36 more rows

4. Using tidyr and dplyr where appropriate, construct a dataframe where carriers are along the columns and the rows are the avg dep_delays flown by each character in a month

flights |> 
  group_by(month, carrier) |>
  summarise(avg_dep_delay = mean(dep_delay, na.rm = TRUE)) |>
  pivot_wider(names_from = carrier, values_from = avg_dep_delay)
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'month'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

5. Calculate the proportion of flights that were delayed but arrived on or before time.

# creates a table of all the flights here dep_delay is bigger than 0 and where those flights arrived on or before time
flights_delayed <- flights |> 
  filter(dep_delay > 0 & arr_delay <=0)

# calculates the proportionof flights
nrow(flights_delayed)/ nrow(flights)
[1] 0.1052391

common_routes <- flights |>
  group_by(origin, dest) |>
  summarise(num_airlines = n_distinct(carrier)) |>
  filter(num_airlines >1)
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'origin'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

6.2 For each of those routes, calculate the avg arrival delay for each airline

avg_arrival_delay <-  flights |>
  inner_join(common_routes, by = c("origin", "dest")) |>
  group_by(origin, dest, carrier) |>
  summarise(avg_arr_delay = mean(arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE))
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'origin', 'dest'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.
avg_arrival_delay
# A tibble: 343 × 4
# Groups:   origin, dest [128]
   origin dest  carrier avg_arr_delay
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>           <dbl>

 9 EWR    BNA   EV              17.7 
10 EWR    BNA   WN              -2.13
# ℹ 333 more rows
#Find the names of these airlines
avg_airline_arr_delay <- avg_arrival_delay |>
  inner_join(airlines, by = "carrier") |>
  select(origin, dest, name, avg_arr_delay)

6.3 For each of those routes, identify the airline with the worst and best average arrival delay

best_worst_airlines <-  avg_airline_arr_delay |>
  group_by(origin, dest) |>
  summarise( best_airline = name[which.min(avg_arr_delay)],
             best_delay = min(avg_arr_delay),
             worst_airline = name[which.max(avg_arr_delay)],
             worst_delay = max(avg_arr_delay))
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'origin'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.
best_worst_airlines
# A tibble: 128 × 6
# Groups:   origin [3]
   origin dest  best_airline             best_delay worst_airline    worst_delay
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>                         <dbl> <chr>                  <dbl>

 2 EWR    AUS   Southwest Airlines Co.      -11.2   United Air Line…        4.28
 3 EWR    BDL   ExpressJet Airlines Inc.      6.78  United Air Line…       22.6 
 4 EWR    BNA   Southwest Airlines Co.       -2.13  ExpressJet Airl…       17.7

6.4 Identify the route with the biggest difference between the best and worst performing airlines

max_difference_route <- best_worst_airlines |>
  mutate(arr_delay_diff = worst_delay - best_delay) |>
  arrange(desc(arr_delay_diff)) 
  
head(max_difference_route, 1)
# A tibble: 1 × 7
# Groups:   origin [1]
  origin dest  best_airline  best_delay worst_airline worst_delay arr_delay_diff
  <chr>  <chr> <chr>              <dbl> <chr>               <dbl>          <dbl>
1 JFK    ATL   Endeavor Air…       1.40 ExpressJet A…         128           127.

6.5 Determine the reason for the difference

flights |>
  filter(origin == max_difference_route$origin, 
         dest == max_difference_route$dest) |>
  group_by(carrier) |>
  summarise(num_flights = n()) |>
  inner_join(airlines, by = "carrier") |>
  select(name, num_flights)
Warning: There were 2 warnings in `filter()`.
The first warning was:
ℹ In argument: `origin == max_difference_route$origin`.
Caused by warning in `origin == max_difference_route$origin`:
! longer object length is not a multiple of shorter object length
ℹ Run `dplyr::last_dplyr_warnings()` to see the 1 remaining warning.
# A tibble: 15 × 2
   name                        num_flights
   <chr>                             <int>
 1 Endeavor Air Inc.                   122
 2 American Airlines Inc.              254
 3 Alaska Airlines Inc.                  7
 4 JetBlue Airways                     345
 5 Delta Air Lines Inc.                423
 6 ExpressJet Airlines Inc.            242
 7 Frontier Airlines Inc.                6
 8 AirTran Airways Corporation          19
 9 Envoy Air                           201
10 SkyWest Airlines Inc.                 2
11 United Air Lines Inc.               347
12 US Airways Inc.                      98
13 Virgin America                       47
14 Southwest Airlines Co.               43
15 Mesa Airlines Inc.                    5

As seen from this output, Eandeavor Air Inc. (best average arrival delay) flies 122 on this route whilst ExpressJet Airlines Inc. (worst average arrival delay) flies 242 times on this route. Some possible reason why they have the greatest difference, could be because Eandeavor Air Inc. might have the fancier and wealthier airline so they could have better engines that allow the plane to fly faster, r they have better ground organisation that plan the schedules for the runways, and they could have better navigation systems to allow them to find the quickest path to the destination without compromising health and safety.

7. Identify all columns with missing entries, typos and other inconsistencies in the dataset

#identify the columns with missing values
missing_val <- colSums(is.na(dataset)) 
missing_val <- missing_val[missing_val > 0]

#identify inconsistencies and typos
categorical_var <- c("gender", "disease_status")
typo_check <- lapply(dataset[categorical_var], unique)
# the typos and inconsistencies
typo_check
$gender
[1] "male"   "female" "femal" 

$disease_status
[1] "diseased" "healthy"  "Healthy"

For an improvement suggestion: both columns, gender and disease_status can be tured into binary variables since in this dataset, both columns only have 2 different observed options for each.
